Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: What's the question? A cross-linguistic investigation into compositional and pragmatic constraints on the question under discussion

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The greatest value of language resides in its meaning, in the information that is exchanged in discourse. This project is part of a broad scholarly effort to find out how that meaning is determined, and to identify what inferences can be drawn from what is said. Recent research on meaning in language, including much published work by the four PIs on this project, shows that the meaning of a sentence is dramatically affected by the context in which the sentence is uttered. Specifically, the three-institution project team has shown in past work how the meaning of a sentence is greatly affected by what question the speaker seeks to address. The fact that a sentence meaning can only be fully grasped in terms of the question the uttered sentence answers creates a problem because the question addressed by a given utterance is typically implicit. So, often a listener can only fully understand the meaning of an uttered sentence by recreating the question that was answered. To do this, the listener must reason from many available clues, for example the intonation used in the utterance, and what is known of the speaker's intentions. The goal of this project is to conduct empirical and theoretical work which will identify the process by which implicit questions are revealed.

The work to be undertaken in this project is of intrinsic interest in understanding human culture and human communication, and also has significant practical applications, for example in the field of Natural Language Processing. To build computers that can understand and use language, the features that inform human language understanding must be identified. The project also offers advanced training opportunities for young researchers at US institutions, develops experimental and other research methodologies that can impact a broad range of fields, and analyzes a foundational problem in language which is related to strategically valuable natural language technology.

The project is set in the context of a Question Under Discussion model in which the context incorporates a dynamically evolving stack of questions. The problem for this model is to figure out what question is addressed by any given stretch of discourse. Three types of constraint on the question will be explored cross-linguistically: lexical constraints contributed by, for instance, focus sensitive expressions and factive predicates, information-structural constraints, including those imposed by intonation and cleft constructions, and contextual constraints, such as Gricean principles. This goal is pursued by expanding methodologies which the three-institution team has jointly pioneered in previous work: a mix of experimental research, corpus-based studies of naturally occurring utterances, and cross-linguistic fieldwork. The development effort is spearheaded with English and Paraguayan Guaraní (Tupí-Guaraní) and selective work is performed on other languages to test aspects of the work that are particularly germane, including K'iche' and Kaqchikel (both Mayan), Hungarian (Ugric) and Tagalog (Austronesian). Throughout the project, there will be an emphasis on the development of data-collection methods appropriate for use with theoretically untrained native speakers

POR.DRECONTENT:
To understand the goals and results of this research project, we must start from the following observation: every complex utterance can convey multiple pieces of content, and different contents in different circumstances.  As an example, consider the sentence "Scientists say that there is water on Mars." This sentence can certainly be used to convey that there is a particular thing that (some group of) scientists say. It might also be used to convey that the speaker believes (to some degree) the thing that scientists are saying; although it might also be used to convey the opposite, for example, if the speaker has previously said that she does not believe anything that scientists say. Clearly, it can be important for a listener (or reader) to recognize whether or not the speaker (or writer) intends to convey belief or disbelief about this content, or intends to remain neutral. Suppose for example that the listener is a student trying to determine whether they are being told that there is or is not water on Mars. Or suppose that the content being attributed to scientists was something much less neutral; for example, a controversial claim about gender or racial differences. In this case, it could matter very much whether the audience understands the speaker to be conveying belief in this claim, or merely to be reporting that it has been said by (some) scientists.
    This collaborative project has studied the properties of sentences and of the contexts in which sentences are produced which determine whether certain potential messages are understood as actual messages. In particular, the project has focused on what is communicated by utterances of sentences of the type just discussed (the "scientists say..." sentence), as well as variants of these sentences such as negated versions ("Scientists do not say that...") or question forms ("Do scientists say that...?"). Specifically, we have studied the circumstances under which the speaker or writer of a sentence of this form is understood to be committed to the content of the subordinate clause (in our example, the clause "there is water on Mars"). To do this, we created a database, which we call the CommitmentBank, of 1200 attested examples of utterances of sentences of this type, along with the context in which the utterance was made, drawn from newspapers, talk shows, and a variety of other sources. We then created online experiments to elicit judgments from participants about the degree to which the producer of the utterance was committed to the content of the subordinate clause. This provided us with a new, rich resource to study how such sentences are interpreted.
    One of the things we learned from the CommitmentBank is that the main verb of the sentence (e.g. "say," vs. "know" vs. "believe") makes an important difference to judgements, but in ways that are surprising in light of prior research; for example, subordinate clauses following the verb ?tell? are highly likely to be understood as commitments of the speaker, even though, of course, it is perfectly possible to tell someone something untrue. We also learned from the CommitmentBank that judgements of commitment to embedded content are highly variable, suggesting that it is extremely difficult for a speaker/writer to be certain that use of a particular sentence form will reliably convey to their audience the set of commitments that are intended.
    The CommitmentBank is now freely available. There is clearly a great deal more to be done to answer the questions with which we began this project, and we look forward to contributions made by other researchers using the resource we created as part of this work.
